Or, do you have a link to the Dockerfile or the image up in a docker registry?

Otherwise I can get you a Dockerfile.

I see a bunch of SELinux errors on the host, which is a Fedora 27, every time this crushes.
Seems like this could be a mixed C++ standard library toolchain issue -- [~kou] do you know what the policy is for using Trusty packages on Debian Jessie platform?

You can't use Ubuntu Trusty packages on Debian Jessie.

Can you try to use Debian Stretch or Ubuntu Trusty? They have packages for their platform.
It works fine with Debian Stretch or Ubuntu Trusty. It seems to be a package/toolchain mixing issues. Sorry for the trouble.

It works fine in Ubuntu Trusty if I use the default g++ compiler to compile this example.

On the other hand, I still get the Segmentation Fault if I use the g++-4.9 compiler from ppa:ubuntu-toolchain-r/test. 

Is it because arrow is compiled with g++ and I compile this example with g++-4.9?
Let's set up a Dockerfile so we can try to reproduce

See the attached {{Dokerfile}} and {{foo.cpp}}. You should be able to reproduce with:
{code:java}
> docker build .
...
Step 18/18 : RUN /a.out
---> Running in de9d8736cf20
Segmentation fault (core dumped)
The command '/bin/sh -c /a.out' returned a non-zero code: 139{code}

[~kou] could this issue be caused by the differences in the {{rules}} file used to build Ubuntu Trusty packages vs. other Debian packages?
{code:java}
> diff debian/rules debian.ubuntu-trusty/rules
12,16c12
< 	dh $@ --with gir,autoreconf
< 
< override_dh_autoreconf:
< 	dh_autoreconf \
< 	  --sourcedirectory=c_glib
---
> 	dh $@ --with gir
25,30c21
< 	  -DARROW_PYTHON=ON \
< 	  -DARROW_BOOST_USE_SHARED=ON \
< 	  -DARROW_ORC=ON \
< 	  -DPythonInterp_FIND_VERSION=ON \
< 	  -DPythonInterp_FIND_VERSION_MAJOR=3 \
< 	  -DARROW_GPU=ON
---
> 	  -DARROW_ORC=ON
56a48,49
> 	mv debian/tmp/usr/lib/*/girepository-1.0/	\
> 	  debian/tmp/usr/lib/
{code}

I did some tests and it does not look like these differences help with the issue.

On the other hand, I compiled Arrow using {{g++-4.9}} and the issue is gone.

Thanks. I confirmed it.

I also confirmed the followings:

  * Apache Arrow C++ compiled with g++-4.8 + -DCMAKE_BUILD_TYPE=Debug and foo.cpp compiled with g++-4.9 work well

  * Apache Arrow C++ compiled with g++-4.8 + -DCMAKE_BUILD_TYPE=Release and foo.cpp compiled with g++-4.9 don't work (crashed)

 I don't know why...

BTW, why do you want to use g++-4.9?

I'm linking Arrow to a "plugin" which I load in SciDB. SciDB is complied with g++-4.9.

I'm also trying to use Ubuntu Trusty packages on Debian Jessie (I know this is not advised) but the problem disappears if I compile Arrow with g++ 4.9.
PoolBuffer is no longer a public API per ARROW-2893. Use the {{arrow::Allocate*}} APIs instead
